item.title: Do You Need a Content Delivery Network?
item.description:
The way we deliver content online is evolving rapidly. While you could once manage a website with just a computer and a few phone lines, today’s high-definition video and nationwide audiences demand far more resources. This is where content delivery networks (CDNs) come in. Think of a CDN as a specialized web hosting service. Just as you can host your website on your own server or outsource it, you can also choose between managing your content distribution or relying on a CDN...

item.title: Latest Evidence Of An Ethernet Juggernaut
item.description:
A powerful force is transforming the telecommunications industry, shifting it from traditional telegraphy and telephony to a digital packet-based system. This revolution, driven by Ethernet technology, is swiftly changing how our communication networks operate. This shift towards Ethernet in metropolitan and long-distance networks highlights the dominance of digital networks, especially local area networks (LANs), in communication. While voice calls once dominated global traffic, data and video now reign supreme. Video, in particular, is driving the expansion of content delivery networks (CDNs) to handle high-definition content efficiently...

item.title: Yes, You Can Afford a Content Delivery Network
item.description:
The internet is great for communication, allowing businesses to connect with anyone globally at a low cost and creating countless opportunities. However, this popularity has led to congestion, potentially slowing down websites. You can work around this issue without sacrificing connectivity. Large content providers use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) to bypass internet congestion. CDNs don’t connect directly to users but deliver content through servers near service providers, resulting in faster speeds...

item.title: AT&T Sees the Video Tsunami Coming
item.description:

Even the concept of “unlimited” bandwidth offered by providers today comes with hidden caps due to network strain. AT&T is one company actively addressing this challenge, not just by increasing general internet capacity but by adding 400 Gbps to its Content Delivery Network (CDN). Think of a CDN as a dedicated express lane running parallel to the public internet highway...

item.title: Your Own Private Information Superhighway
item.description:

These slowdowns are especially common in high-traffic areas or on connections with limited capacity.
